section.title: Obtaining Waf
section.para: The Waf project is located on Google Code The current Waf version requires an interpreter for the Python programming language such as cPython (http://www.python.org) 2.3 to 3.1 or Jython ≥ 2.5 (http://www.jython.org). Note that Waf requires bzip2 compression support, which may be unavailable in self-compiled cPython installations.

sect2.title: Using the Waf binary
sect2.para:
The Waf binary does not require any installation whatsoever. It may be executed directly from a writeable folder. Just rename it into "waf" if necessary:
$ wget http://waf.googlecode.com/files/waf-1.5.11 $ mv waf-1.5.11 waf && chmod 755 waf

sect2.title: Generating the Waf binary from the source code
sect2.para:
The Waf binary creation requires a Python interpreter in version 2.4 to 2.6. The source code is processed to support Python 2.3 and Python 3.
$ wget http://waf.googlecode.com/files/waf-1.5.11.tar.bz2 $ tar xjvf waf-1.5.11.tar.bz2 $ cd waf-1.5.11 $ ./waf-light --make-waf

section.title: Installing Waf on a system
section.para:
Installing the Waf script on a system is discouraged:
Interpreter version: unlike the Waf script, the installed version will not run by using Python 3 Operating systems: Waf cannot be installed on Windows (yet) Installation: installation is cumbersome, and requires administrative privileges Waf versions: users rarely install the appropriate software version (too old, too new, bugs) Bugs: different Waf versions may result in broken builds Size: Waf is small enough to be redistributed (about 80kB)
Instead, redistribute the appropriate Waf script along the sources using it.

Installation require a Python interpreter in the versions 2.4 to 2.6. It may require administrator or root privileges, depending on the target folder (prefix).
# ./waf-light configure --prefix=/usr/ # ./waf-light install

Likewise, Waf can be uninstalled using:
# ./waf-light --prefix=/usr/ # ./waf-light uninstall

section.title: Running Waf
section.para:
The Waf script can be used directly from a writeable folder:
$ ./waf
Or, if the executable permissions are not set properly:
$ python waf

By default, the Waf script uncompresses its library in the current directory, in a hidden folder. This means the Waf script must reside in a writable folder. The naming enables different Waf versions to be executed from the same folders:
$ ls -ld .waf* .waf-1.5.11-2c924e3f453eb715218b9cc852291170
Obviously, the Waf script will not do much without a project to process including at least various files. The impatient might want to have a look at the examples provided under the folder demos of the Waf source code distribution.
